subjects.subject: Physics
subjects.textbook: Physics – Textbook for Class XII (Part I & II)

chapters.title: Electric Charges and Fields
topics: Electric flux and Gauss’s law (applications to simple symmetric cases)

notes.summary: Introduces electric charge, the inverse‑square law of interaction, and electric fields; uses Gauss’s law to compute fields in symmetric charge distributions.
key_points: Like charges repel and unlike charges attract; charge is conserved and quantized.
Coulomb’s law gives the force between point charges and combines using superposition for many charges.
Electric field describes force per unit positive test charge and is visualised with field lines.
Gauss’s law relates electric flux through a closed surface to enclosed charge and simplifies field calculations for high symmetry.

chapters.title: Electrostatic Potential and Capacitance
topics: Capacitors and capacitance; series and parallel combinations

notes.summary: Connects electric field to potential energy per unit charge and develops the concept of capacitance and energy storage in electric fields.
key_points: Potential difference is work done per unit charge in moving a test charge between two points.
Field is the negative gradient of potential; equipotential surfaces are perpendicular to field lines.
Capacitance measures the ability to store charge per unit potential, enhanced by dielectrics and geometry.
Capacitors in series and parallel combine with reciprocal and direct addition rules respectively.

chapters.title: Current Electricity
topics: Electric current and drift of electrons
Series and parallel combinations of resistors

notes.summary: Develops current flow in conductors, circuit laws, and practical bridge and potentiometer techniques for precise measurements.
key_points: Current is due to drift motion of electrons under an applied electric field; resistivity depends on material and temperature.
Ohm’s law relates current to potential difference at constant temperature; deviations occur in some materials.
Kirchhoff’s laws allow analysis of complex networks using conservation of charge and energy.
Bridge circuits and potentiometers achieve accurate resistance and emf measurements.

chapters.title: Moving Charges and Magnetism
topics: Magnetic force on a moving charge and current‑carrying conductor
Biot–Savart law and Ampere’s circuital law
Magnetic field of a straight wire, circular loop, and solenoid
Torque on a current loop and moving coil galvanometer

notes.summary: Relates motion of charges to magnetic fields and forces; derives fields for simple current geometries and explains galvanometer operation.
key_points: A moving charge experiences a force perpendicular to both velocity and magnetic field.
Biot–Savart and Ampere’s laws compute magnetic fields for symmetric conductor arrangements.
Solenoids and toroids create nearly uniform internal magnetic fields with controllable strength.
A current loop behaves as a magnetic dipole and experiences torque in a field, enabling galvanometer design.

chapters.title: Magnetism and Matter
topics: Bar magnet as an equivalent solenoid

notes.summary: Discusses magnetic response of materials, Earth’s magnetic field, and models a bar magnet as a solenoid.
key_points: Material response to magnetic field is quantified by magnetisation and susceptibility.
Diamagnets are weakly repelled, paramagnets weakly attracted, and ferromagnets strongly attracted and can be permanently magnetised.
Earth behaves like a giant magnet with inclination, declination, and horizontal component of field.

chapters.title: Electromagnetic Induction
topics: Lenz’s law and conservation of energy
Self and mutual induction; inductors and energy in magnetic field

notes.summary: Explains how changing magnetic fields induce emf and current, leading to generators and inductors.
key_points: An emf is induced when magnetic flux through a circuit changes with time.
Lenz’s law gives direction of induced current to oppose flux change, ensuring energy conservation.
Inductors store energy in magnetic fields and oppose changes in current.

chapters.title: Alternating Current
topics: AC voltage and current; RMS values
Reactance and impedance of L, C, and RLC circuits

notes.summary: Introduces AC circuits and resonance, and shows how transformers step voltages up or down efficiently.
key_points: AC quantities vary sinusoidally; RMS values represent effective heating equivalents.
Capacitors and inductors oppose changes in voltage/current, introducing phase differences.
At resonance, an RLC circuit draws maximum current; power factor influences real power delivered.
Transformers use electromagnetic induction to change AC voltages with minimal losses.

chapters.title: Electromagnetic Waves
topics: Maxwell’s equations (qualitative) and prediction of EM waves
Nature and properties of EM waves
Electromagnetic spectrum and uses of different bands

notes.summary: Shows that time‑varying electric and magnetic fields propagate as electromagnetic waves across the spectrum.
key_points: Changing electric fields generate magnetic fields and vice versa, allowing self‑sustaining waves.
EM waves are transverse, travel at speed of light in vacuum, and carry energy and momentum.
Different frequency bands (radio to gamma) have distinct applications and interactions with matter.

chapters.title: Ray Optics and Optical Instruments
topics: Lens maker’s formula (concept) and thin lens formula
Refraction through prisms; dispersion and deviation
Optical instruments: microscope and telescope (basic ideas)

notes.summary: Uses the ray model to analyse image formation by lenses and prisms and introduces basic optical instruments.
key_points: Snell’s law governs refraction; total internal reflection enables devices like optical fibres.
Thin lens formula relates object distance, image distance, and focal length.
Prisms deviate and disperse light based on wavelength dependence of refractive index.
Compound microscopes and astronomical telescopes magnify small or distant objects using lens combinations.

chapters.title: Wave Optics
topics: Young’s double slit experiment and fringe width
Polarisation of light and its applications

notes.summary: Treats light as a wave to explain interference, diffraction, and polarisation phenomena.
key_points: Superposition of coherent waves leads to constructive and destructive interference patterns.
Diffraction limits resolution of optical instruments and depends on aperture size and wavelength.
Polarisation reveals transverse nature of light and is used in glare reduction and stress analysis.

chapters.title: Dual Nature of Radiation and Matter

notes.summary: Introduces quantum ideas showing that light and matter exhibit both wave and particle properties.
key_points: Photoelectric effect demonstrates particle aspects of light with energy quantised in photons.
de Broglie suggested all matter has associated wavelength inversely proportional to momentum.
Electron diffraction confirms wave nature of particles at small scales.

notes.summary: Summarises early atomic models and Bohr’s quantised orbits explaining hydrogen’s line spectrum.
key_points: Rutherford’s nuclear atom could not explain atomic stability and discrete spectra.
Bohr postulated quantised angular momentum and allowed orbits with fixed energies.
Transitions between levels emit or absorb photons of specific frequencies.

notes.summary: Explores structure and stability of nuclei and energy processes in radioactivity and nuclear reactions.
key_points: Nuclei consist of protons and neutrons bound by strong nuclear forces.
Radioactive decay follows probabilistic laws characterised by half‑life.
Mass defect corresponds to binding energy that holds the nucleus together.

chapters.title: Semiconductor Electronics
topics: p–n junction diode and I–V characteristics
Diode as rectifier; Zener diode as voltage regulator
Basic transistor action and simple applications

notes.summary: Covers semiconductor physics leading to diodes and transistors with basic electronic applications.
key_points: Doping modifies semiconductor conductivity creating n‑type and p‑type materials.
p–n junctions allow current more easily in one direction enabling rectification.
Zener diodes maintain nearly constant output voltage in regulation circuits.

subjects.subject: Chemistry
subjects.textbook: Chemistry – Textbook for Class XII (Part I & II)

chapters.title: Solid State
topics: Classification of solids: crystalline and amorphous

notes.summary: Describes arrangement of particles in solids, types of unit cells, and defects that influence properties.
key_points: Crystalline solids have long‑range order while amorphous solids lack regularity.
Unit cells repeat in three dimensions to form crystal lattices; packing determines density.
Point defects like vacancies and interstitials affect conductivity and mechanical strength.

chapters.title: Solutions
topics: Types of solutions and concentration terms
Colligative properties and abnormal molar masses

notes.summary: Studies properties depending on number of solute particles and deviations from ideal behaviour.
key_points: Concentration can be expressed as mole fraction, molarity, molality, etc.
Vapour pressure lowering and colligative effects depend on solute particle count.
Association or dissociation leads to abnormal molar masses captured by van’t Hoff factor.

notes.summary: Relates redox chemistry to electricity generation and storage, and explains corrosion processes.
key_points: EMF of a cell arises from redox reactions at electrodes and depends on concentrations and temperature.
Nernst equation quantifies potential under non‑standard conditions.
Industrial electrolysis and protective methods control corrosion and deposit metals.

chapters.title: Chemical Kinetics
topics: Rate of reaction and rate laws
Integrated rate equations (zero and first order)

notes.summary: Explains how fast reactions proceed, how rates depend on concentration and temperature, and the role of catalysts.
key_points: Rate laws express dependence of rate on reactant concentrations.
First‑order reactions have constant half‑life independent of initial concentration.
Catalysts lower activation energy and increase reaction rate without being consumed.

notes.summary: Deals with phenomena at surfaces, including adsorption, colloidal stability, and catalytic action.
key_points: Adsorption is accumulation at surfaces and can be physical or chemical in nature.
Colloids consist of dispersed phase and dispersion medium showing Tyndall effect.
Surface area and active sites control catalytic efficiency in many industrial processes.

chapters.title: General Principles and Processes of Isolation of Elements

notes.summary: Outlines metallurgical steps to obtain metals from ores using chemical and electrochemical methods.
key_points: Choice of extraction method depends on metal reactivity and ore nature.
Ellingham diagrams guide selection of reducing agents based on Gibbs energy.
Electrolytic refining gives high‑purity metals for technology applications.

notes.summary: Surveys trends and important compounds of Groups 15–18 including nitrogen, oxygen, halogens, and noble gases.
key_points: Variations in oxidation state and bonding result in diverse chemistry across the p‑block.
First-row anomalies arise from small size, high electronegativity, and lack of d‑orbitals.
Industrial and environmental relevance includes oxoacids, halogenation, and inert gases.

chapters.title: The d‑ and f‑Block Elements
topics: Colour, variable oxidation states, and catalytic behaviour

notes.summary: Discusses unique features of transition and inner transition elements and their technological roles.
key_points: Partially filled d/f orbitals lead to colour, magnetism, and catalytic activity.
Lanthanide contraction affects properties across the series.
d‑block complexes are central to materials, catalysis, and bioinorganic chemistry.

chapters.title: Coordination Compounds
topics: Bonding theories (valence bond and crystal field basics)

notes.summary: Introduces the structure, bonding, and properties of metal–ligand complexes with real-life applications.
key_points: Ligand type and arrangement determine complex geometry and properties.
Crystal field splitting explains colour and magnetism in many complexes.
Coordination compounds feature in metalloproteins, analytical reagents, and catalysis.

notes.summary: Covers preparation and reactivity of halo derivatives of alkanes and arenes with focus on substitution mechanisms.
key_points: Reactivity depends on substrate structure, leaving group ability, and solvent effects.
Aryl halides differ from alkyl halides due to resonance and partial double bond character.
Some halogenated compounds pose environmental risks and require careful handling.

notes.summary: Details structures and reactions of oxygen‑containing organic compounds central to synthesis and industry.
key_points: Acidity of phenols arises from resonance‑stabilised phenoxide ion.
Alcohols undergo substitution and oxidation to yield aldehydes, ketones, or acids.
Ethers are relatively inert but useful as solvents and protective groups.

chapters.title: Aldehydes, Ketones and Carboxylic Acids
topics: Acidity of carboxylic acids and derivatives

notes.summary: Explores electrophilic carbonyl chemistry and acidity trends in related functional groups.
key_points: Polarised C=O bond makes carbonyl carbon susceptible to nucleophilic attack.
Reactivity patterns enable key synthetic transformations and tests.
Carboxylic acids show resonance‑stabilised conjugate bases explaining acidity.

chapters.title: Amines
topics: Diazonium salts and their synthetic utility

notes.summary: Covers nitrogen‑containing organics, their basic character, and versatile transformations via diazonium chemistry.
key_points: Amines act as bases and nucleophiles, with basicity influenced by substituents and solvation.
Diazonium salts enable formation of diverse functional groups on aromatic rings.
Amines appear in biomolecules, drugs, dyes, and polymers.

notes.summary: Introduces organic molecules central to life and their functional roles.
key_points: Structure of biomolecules informs their roles in energy storage, catalysis, and heredity.
Proteins are polymers of amino acids with complex folding patterns.
Nucleic acids store genetic information and control protein synthesis.

notes.summary: Discusses macromolecules formed by polymerisation and their applications and sustainability issues.
key_points: Monomer structure determines polymer properties and processing.
Copolymers tune material properties for specific applications.
Biodegradable polymers aim to reduce environmental burden.

chapters.title: Chemistry in Everyday Life
topics: Impact and safe use of chemicals

notes.summary: Shows how chemical principles underlie pharmaceuticals, food additives, and detergents used daily.
key_points: Drug action often involves specific interactions with biological targets.
Preservatives, sweeteners, and antioxidants must meet safety standards.
Surfactants emulsify oils and aid cleaning but require responsible disposal.

notes.summary: Overviews how organisms reproduce and how life cycles are organised across taxa.
key_points: Asexual reproduction produces clones; sexual reproduction generates variation.
Life span and timing of reproduction reflect evolutionary adaptations.

notes.summary: Explains reproductive structures and processes unique to angiosperms.
key_points: Male and female gametophytes develop within anthers and ovules.
Double fertilisation forms zygote and endosperm, characteristic of flowering plants.

notes.summary: Describes human reproductive anatomy and physiology from gametogenesis to birth.
key_points: Hormones regulate gamete production and reproductive cycles.
Embryo development occurs in stages supported by maternal tissues.

notes.summary: Promotes informed choices and awareness for healthy reproduction and disease prevention.
key_points: Education and access to healthcare improve reproductive outcomes.
Safe practices and timely treatment prevent transmission of infections.

notes.summary: Explores genetic principles that determine trait transmission and variation.
key_points: Monohybrid and dihybrid crosses illustrate segregation and independent assortment.
Linkage and crossing over modify expected ratios and map gene positions.

chapters.title: Molecular Basis of Inheritance
topics: Genetic code and regulation of gene expression

notes.summary: Describes how genetic information is stored, copied, and expressed into functional products.
key_points: Complementary base pairing underlies replication fidelity and information transfer.
Gene expression is regulated at multiple steps to meet cellular needs.

chapters.title: Evolution
topics: Origin of life and evolutionary evidence
Mechanisms of evolution: variation, selection, drift

notes.summary: Outlines processes that drive biological evolution and the evidence supporting them.
key_points: Natural selection acts on heritable variation to shape populations over time.
Genetic drift and gene flow also change allele frequencies, especially in small populations.

notes.summary: Covers pathogens, body defence mechanisms, and public health measures against disease.
key_points: Innate and adaptive immunity protect against infections.
Vaccines prime immune memory and reduce disease incidence.

chapters.title: Strategies for Enhancement in Food Production

notes.summary: Explains methods to increase yield and quality of food resources sustainably.
key_points: Selective breeding and biotechnology produce improved crop varieties and livestock.
Microbial and tissue culture techniques supplement conventional agriculture.

notes.summary: Highlights beneficial roles of microbes in industry, environment, and agriculture.
key_points: Fermentation and microbial synthesis produce valuable products.
Microbial processes clean wastewater and generate renewable energy.

chapters.title: Biotechnology: Principles and Processes
topics: Steps in gene cloning and selection

notes.summary: Introduces genetic engineering techniques enabling targeted modification of organisms.
key_points: Restriction enzymes, ligases, and vectors underpin rDNA methods.
Selection markers identify recombinant clones for further use.

notes.summary: Surveys real‑world applications of biotech in health and agriculture, noting ethical and safety concerns.
key_points: Transgenic crops can resist pests and improve yield.
Biopharmaceuticals and diagnostics rely on recombinant DNA methods.

notes.summary: Begins ecology with organism–environment interactions and population dynamics.
key_points: Environmental factors and niches determine distribution and survival.
Population growth models describe changes over time with limiting factors.

notes.summary: Explains energy and material movement through ecosystems and their organisation.
key_points: Producers, consumers, and decomposers form functional components.
Energy flows unidirectionally while nutrients cycle through biogeochemical loops.

chapters.title: Biodiversity and Conservation
topics: Conservation strategies: in situ and ex situ

notes.summary: Emphasises value of biodiversity and methods to protect it at genetic, species, and ecosystem levels.
key_points: Species richness and endemism vary with geography and climate.
Protected areas and community participation are key to conservation.
